entry.summary: Sometimes cleaning Jekyll‚Äôs cache can improve slow (~60s) incremental build times. jekyll clean will do this. If you continue to experience --incremental build (make serve-quick) time issues, please let us know!

entry.summary: ADRs are documents that captures an important architectural decision made along with its context and consequences.

entry.summary: We would like to recognise and thank all of the reviewers who have contributed to the GTN tutorials; your efforts are greatly appreciated, and we are grateful for your contributions to the GTN community. Today, we are highlighting your efforts on every single learning material across the GTN.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: Credit where it's due: GTN Reviewers in the spotlight

entry.summary: Here, we provide a clear set of instructions for updating a GTN tutorial that uses the Galaxy interface for performing analysis. The GTN, and Galaxy, have a number of features to make it as reproducible and shareable as possible, so navigating what needs to be done for an overall update may feel daunting - but not anymore!
entry.title: üìö New Tutorial: Updating tool versions in a tutorial

entry.summary: If you are working on your own training materials and want preview them online without installing anything on your computer, you can do this using GitHub CodeSpaces! Everybody gets 60 free hours of CodeSpaces per month.
entry.title: üìö New Tutorial: Running the GTN website online using GitHub CodeSpaces

entry.summary: Extracting data from the GTN‚Äôs Git history isn‚Äôt that difficult, but it requires some internal knowledge of how the GTN‚Äôs Jekyll-based codebase works. Here we‚Äôll document what we‚Äôve done!
entry.title: üìö New Tutorial: Single Cell Publication - Data Analysis

entry.summary: We‚Äôll use some ggplot and tidyverse code to plot the data we collected in part 1
entry.title: üìö New Tutorial: Single Cell Publication - Data Plotting

entry.summary: There is no specific certification regarding the implementation of the FAIR-by-Design Methodology when developing learning materials for GTN.
entry.title: ‚ùì New FAQ: Is there a certification available for the FAIR-by-Design Methodology?

entry.summary: The FAIR-by-Design Methodology stages can be relatively easily adapted to the processes for designing other FAIR objects.
entry.title: ‚ùì New FAQ: Can the FAIR-by-Design Methodology be used for FAIR development of other types of resources?

entry.summary: The tutorial has been specifically adapted to the rules and options available in GTN. However, the general FAIR-by-Design Methodology is platform agnostic and can be applied to any environment.
entry.title: ‚ùì New FAQ: Can this tutorial be adapted to other instructional development platforms?
‚ùì New FAQ: Input Histories & Answer Keys

entry.summary: If you are adding a tutorial, annotating the pre-requisites is an important task! It will help ensure learners know what they need to know before starting the tutorial. They also let instructors plan a schedule optimally.
entry.title: ‚ùì New FAQ: Annotating Pre-requisites

entry.summary: If you are writing a tutorial or slides, there are two ways to annotate contributions:
entry.title: ‚ùì New FAQ: Using the new Contributions Annotation framework

entry.summary: Since the last time we announced GTN news posting via Google Form, we‚Äôve found that this has been an excellent fit for the community and decided to greatly expand the use of Google Forms for GTN contributions.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: Simplifying GTN contribution with Google Forms

entry.summary: We recently presented the GTN at the 2024 Galaxy Community Conference. This presentation was a summary of the updates and new features that were added to the GTN in the past year.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: So many new features! GTN 2023-2024 Updates

entry.summary: Many GTN tutorials already have recordings. These recordings were made by members of the community for a variety of (online) training events.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: GTN Video Library 2.0: 107 hours of learning across 154 videos

entry.summary: With growing access and interest in sequencing data, Galaxy is a knight in shining armor for wet lab scientists hoping to analyze their own data. With long term intentions of increasing access to bioinformatic analyses, the Galaxy Training Network (GTN) creates a safe space where non-computer-scientists may analyze their own data and even learn to code: an invaluable skill in today‚Äôs scientific world. Galaxy introduced me to brand new skills as an undergraduate and ultimately changed the trajectory of my career. Here is my story as a biology undergraduate with no coding experience turned GTN contributor &, eventually, coding bioinformatician: thanks to Galaxy.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: From GTN Intern to Tutorial Author to Bioinformatician

entry.summary: We are happy to announce the Galaxy Training Academy 2024, a global online training event, where learners can get to know Galaxy and learn how to analyze data for various research topics.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: Open Call for Trainers for the Galaxy Training Academy

entry.summary: The Galaxy Training Network (GTN) has reached an exciting milestone: our 400th tutorial! This achievement is a testament to the dedication and hard work of our community of educators, researchers, and developers over the last 9 years.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: Celebrating the Milestone: 400 Tutorials on the Galaxy Training Network!
üì∞ New Post: Standards compliant‚Ñ¢ training news via RSS/Atom

entry.summary: For many tools in Galaxy, the GTN offers a variety of guides, practical examples, and help throughout it‚Äôs many tutorials.

entry.summary: As part of the EuroScienceGateway and in cooperation with Onedata and EGI we are providing all GTN training data on a publicly accessible cloud storage.

entry.summary: Are you organizing a training event using GTN materials? You can now add your event directly to the GTN!

entry.summary: We are happy to report that over the years of our fruitful collaboration with ELIXIR TeSS, all GTN materials should receive a perfect score on the FAIR-Checker.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: Perfectly FAIR Training!

entry.summary: At the Galaxy Training Network we are really committed to ensuring our training materials are Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: Cool URLs Don't Change, GTN URLs don't either.

entry.summary: This learning path aims to teach you the basics of navigating the Galaxy training Github repository, and turning your ace training materials and workflows into Galaxy sites. For support throughout these tutorials, join our Galaxy [training network on Matrix](https://matrix.to/#/#Galaxy-Training-Network_Lobby:gitter.im) to ask questions!
entry.title: üõ§Ô∏è New Learning pathway: Building training material in Galaxy

entry.summary: Howdy teachers and support staff! We are exploring displaying GTN content directly in the Galaxy Help site, furthering the integration between the GTN and the Galaxy community infrastructure.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: GTN in Discourse

entry.summary: Based on user feedback of the difficulties of the GTN news submission process we have significantly simplified and removed the need for manually editing a YAML file by providing a quick and easy Google Form
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: Simplified GTN News submission via Google Form

entry.title: üì∞ New Post: GTN has left Twitter/X as of October

entry.summary: I recently imported Friends Don‚Äôt Let Friends Make Bad Graphs, a fantastic and educational github repository showcasing some common visualisation mistakes, that was available under an open license, to the GTN. Then the GTN automatically made a video for me.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: Feedback: Easy slide recordings

entry.summary: WorkflowHub
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: Update: Workflow List now searches WorkflowHub.eu, advanced query syntax

entry.summary: The use of snippets is extremely important for asynchronous, remote learning. In this situation as students do not have a teacher immediately on hand, and likely do not have friends or colleagues sitting working with them, they will rely on these boxes to refresh their knowledge and know what to do.
entry.title: ‚ùì New FAQ: Preparing materials for asynchronous learning: Tips

entry.summary: In the context of remote trainings, where a teacher isn‚Äôt synchronously available, ensuring that you have questions throughout your materials for students to check their understanding is incredibly key.
entry.title: ‚ùì New FAQ: Preparing materials for asynchronous learning: Self-Study

entry.summary: When you are running a remote, asynchronous lesson, you‚Äôll want to be sure you collect all student questions and add them back to your tutorial afterwards, as FAQs. This will help other learners as they progress through the materials, and can give you a very easy URL to point your learners to if they get stuck on a particular task.
entry.title: ‚ùì New FAQ: Preparing materials for asynchronous learning: FAQs

entry.summary: If you are running a remote training, and expect your users to follow a specific path, be certain to include the URL parameter to select the pathway to avoid student confusion. Please note that all tutorials using a CYOA should be tagged which will give you a heads up as a trainer.
entry.title: ‚ùì New FAQ: Preparing materials for asynchronous learning: CYOA

entry.summary: We have added a new ‚ÄúUser Preferences‚Äù page for our GTN users! This gives you more control over both how the GTN looks, and works, for you.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: New Feature: GTN User Preferences

entry.summary: June is Pride Month in the US and countries around the world. We have automatically activated the new Progress Pride theme on the home page (Click to Activate) if you hadn‚Äôt already selected a theme.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: GTN Celebrates Pride Month: Alan Hart & M. Tuberculosis

entry.summary: The GTN has set up a very simple ‚Äúredirection‚Äù service based on my.home-assistant.io which Helena discovered after reading some Home Assistant documentation and saw a really neat link which led to her own internal home assistant.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: New Feature: my.galaxy.training

entry.summary: The GTN has implemented ‚Äúclick to run‚Äù workflows! One click, will get you into Galaxy with a workflow imported and ready to run.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: New Feature: Click-to-run Workflows

entry.summary: The internal functions of the GTN have, in the past, not been very well documented. Now we have started the process of fully documenting the functions and modules available to GTN developers.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: New Feature: GTN Rdoc

entry.summary: The GTN has added persistent URL identifiers for our tutorials, slides, and FAQs. Using the gxy.io service, we have reserved GTN namespace for our persistent URLs. These work similarly to DOIs in that they will always point to a specific training material.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: New Feature: Persistent URLs (PURLs) / Shortlinks
‚ùì New FAQ: Defining a Learning Pathway

entry.summary: Introducing Learning Pathways in the GTN! Learning pathways are sets of tutorials curated for you by community experts to form a coherent set of lessons around a topic, building up knowledge step by step.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: New Feature: Learning Pathways!

entry.summary: Numerous other training groups keep ‚ÄúTrainer Directories‚Äù as a way to help students meet trainers in their area, especially for hosting workshops for their local community. There have been a handful of attempts at this in the past, both in galaxyproject/galaxy-maps and in a Google Map on the GTN homepage.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: New Feature: Trainer Directory! (Add yourself today!)

entry.summary: Did you ever wonder which was the number one most used tool in the GTN? There is a new page of Top Tools where we list all of the top tools in the GTN, and which tutorials use them. We guessed ‚Äúupload1‚Äù, but it seems like not every author annotates that step explicitly in their tutorial, and of course it doesn‚Äôt appear in the workflows which we also scan to create this tool listing.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: What are the most used tools in the GTN?

entry.summary: February marks Black History Month in the United States. This year we want to celebrate that by introducing a new theme (Click to Activate), and taking a look at one of the most famous Black figures in Science: Henrietta Lacks whose contribution to science went unremarked and unappreciated for decades while white scientists took credit for advancements built on her cell line.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: GTN Celebrates Black History Month

entry.summary: Prometheus is an increasingly popular monitoring solution whereby sites expose a /metrics endpoint, and then a central Prometheus server can scrape it for data which is then plotted or visualised or alerted upon. We at the GTN are now testing out a prometheus endpoint for our completely static site which we‚Äôll use to expose some maybe useful statistics about the GTN that others can then scrape and display in ways that are useful for them.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: New Feature: Prometheus Metrics endpoint

entry.summary: Our new paper about the Galaxy Training Network has been published this week in Plos Computational Biology: ‚ÄúGalaxy Training: A powerful framework for teaching!‚Äù
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: New GTN paper: "Galaxy Training: A powerful framework for teaching!"

entry.summary: Improving student learning and out comes should always be a goal of teaching. Here we present several strategies to improve student experiences during courses by focusing on how they approach specific problems, and giving them real world applicable solutions to those problems.
entry.title: üìö New Tutorial: Teaching Python

entry.summary: Within the GTN we have had schemas for the various metadata we keep for a long time. It helps us automatically check community contributions to ensure they conform to all of the GTN standards, and will work correctly in our environment.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: GTN Metadata Schemas

entry.summary: Interactive quizzes can be used either alone, or with a classroom of students, to check student‚Äôs knowledge.
entry.title: üìö New Tutorial: Adding Quizzes to your Tutorial

entry.summary: It has been a long discussed feature within the GTN Tutorial Author Community: how can we provide trainees with choice in their tutorials, and how can we as trainers not duplicate large tutorials just to show a slightly different path at one point?
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: New Tutorial Feature: Choose Your Own Tutorial

entry.summary: Further building on the work in the automatic Jupyter Notebook, we‚Äôve now re-written the Jupyter export to be faster, and more importantly added support for R and RMarkdown! Check out an example material. Here we take the content of the tutorial, written like normal GTN markdown, and we automatically convert it to Jupyter Notebooks and now RMarkdown documents! Check out the documentation on how to setup your tutorials to support this.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: New Feature: Automatic RMarkdown

entry.summary: The Galaxy Training Network will now support annotating Funding Agencies on training materials. This is part of our ongoing effort to better annotate how people are contributing to the GTN and recognise all of the sources of contribution.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: Support for annotating Funding Agencies
üì∞ New Post: GTN Sm√∂rg√•sbord 2: Tapas Edition

entry.summary: The GTN does a lot of work to adhere to the best practices for FAIR training materials as set out in Garcia et al. 2020 and a lot of this work is behind-the-scenes or automatic from the infrastructure we provide, and we wanted to highlight that for educators and organisers who want to use GTN materials. This is one of the ways the GTN works to makes itself a fantastic platform training. Find out how contributing simple markdown tutorials can result in fantastically FAIR training.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: New FAQs: How does the GTN stay FAIR and Collaborative

entry.summary: After runnning a number of virtual training events this year (e.g. Sm√∂rg√•sbord, GCC2021), we now have a large collection of training videos around the GTN materials, created by this community.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: New Feature: GTN Video Library

entry.summary: As part of the work for the Gallantries Grant, we wanted to access some of the data from the GTN in a more accessible, API based way. We are working on building a Video Library based on the wild success of our Sm√∂rg√•sbord and GCC2021 events and to support that we wanted to start pulling in data from the GTN to save course authors time and effort when designing their asynchronous courses.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: New Feature: GTN API with OpenAPI 3 specification

entry.summary: Are you one of our amazing GTN Contributors? Were you ever bothered by how slow it was to build the site locally? This is now fixed completely! We have replaced one of the slowest steps of the GTN‚Äôs build process and rewritten it ourselves to be more performant.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: Attention Contributors: GTN Performance Enhancements

entry.summary: Do you use Galaxy for Training? Have your say! Please take a few minutes to let us know about your training experiences.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: Got a minute? Take our survey about Galaxy for training and have your say!

entry.summary: As part of the work for the Gallantries Grant, we found ourselves wanting to teach a number of non-Galaxy tutorials on topics such as Python, Bash, SQL, and Git. Writing the tutorials was always a bit awkward as you would spend a lot of time writing code blocks that would be copied and pasted by students into a terminal. We thought we could do better than that, so we decided we would try to convert these to Jupyter Notebooks where the students could read the training materials and simultaneously execute the code cells directly there with the text! This worked fantastically and now we‚Äôve built this feature into the GTN to make it easier to run all of the coding tutorials.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: New Feature: Automatic Jupyter Notebooks

entry.summary: As you have probably already seen, a feedback form is embedded on the bottom of each tutorial.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: New Feature: a feedback page to aggregate and display feedback answers

entry.summary: One of our community members suggested on twitter that we support alternative formats for accessing our JavaScript based slides, as this can be difficult for users using screen readers. We‚Äôve now added support for ‚Äúplain text slides‚Äù, where we render the slide decks as a single long document.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: Accessibility Improvements

entry.summary: Want to contribute to the GTN without installing anything on your own computer? GitPod provides an online workspace for editing the GTN tutorials, and showing a live preview of the GTN website with your changes. This tutorial shows you how to set up GitPod, how to use it to get a live preview of the GTN website, and how to save any changes you make back to your GitHub fork. This makes it easier than ever to contribute to the GTN!
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: New Tutorial: GitPod for contributing to the GTN

entry.summary: If you are working on your own training materials and want preview them online without installing anything on your computer, you can do this using GitPod!
entry.title: üìö New Tutorial: Running the GTN website online using GitPod

entry.summary: Snippets have received an major overhaul! Snippets/FAQs are small reusable bits of training, often answering a single question. In addition to the general Galaxy snippets, we now also support topic-level and tutorial-level FAQs. This will allow contributors to add common questions and answers to their tutorials, which not only can be included in the tutorial text itself, but are also used to autogenerate an FAQ page for the tutorial or topic listing all common questions (and answers).This will be useful both to participants following tutorials via self-study, and also to instructors preparing for a training event.
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: New Feature: FAQs

entry.summary: Every 3 months we organise one day dedicated to the GTN community! Thursday, May 20th is the next GTN CoFest. We will be working on the training materials, have discussions with the global Galaxy traning community. Do you teach with Galaxy? Want to learn how to add your tutorial to the GTN? New to the community and just want to learn more? Everybody is welcome!
entry.title: üì∞ New Post: Next GTN CoFest May 20, 2021

entry.summary: All the training material which you find on https://training.galaxyproject.org/training-material/ is stored on a GitHub repository (https://github.com/galaxyproject/training-material), a code hosting platform for version control and collaboration. GitHub interface is quite intuitive and simplifies the contributions from anyone.
entry.title: üìö New Tutorial: Contributing with GitHub via its interface

entry.summary: Most of the content is written in GitHub Flavored Markdown with some metadata (or variables) found in YAML files. Everything is stored on a GitHub repository: https://github.com/galaxyproject/training-material.
entry.title: üìö New Tutorial: Contributing with GitHub via command-line

entry.summary: Each training material is related to a topic. All training materials (slides, tutorials, ‚Ä¶) related to a topic are found in a dedicated directory (e.g. transcriptomics directory contains the material related to exome sequencing analysis).
